messageBody:
Simon,

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Simon Chappell"
<simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
>
> On 10/3/06, j_cumps <j_cumps@...> wrote:
> > <controversial>
>
> He he he. Go for it. :-)
>
> > I'm still not convinced of the economics of unit testing at the
> > lowest level.
> > I've been lurking this list for quite some time, attended online
and
> > offline seminars, listened to to Agile, XP and TDD talks, ...
>
> Gotta love theory ... right up until reality smacks it upside the
head.
>
> > And apply it at work.
>
> Now you're talking.
>
> > I am convinced that TDD is a right approach.
>
> Me too.
>
> > I see big value in the agile methods.
>
> Yup.
>
> > But to my feeling unit testing can be done at the requirements
level.
>
> Of course it can. No one around here is likely to say that it can't
> be. Now, that said, we also believe that it brings many benefits at
> the lower levels as well.
>
> > That's why I am thinking about testdriving this approach:
> >
> > 1: Write unit tests only to test the requirements.
>
> Can't individual objects have requirements?
>


Yes, they can.


> > 2: Write the code that implements these requirements, until tests
> > pass.
> > 3: Run the unit tests together with a code coverage tool
> > 4: delete all executable lines of code not covered by the unit
test
>
> If the code was developed with TDD, will there really be much unused
> code kicking around?
>


Some code might just exist because we've written a test for it.



> > </controversial>
>
> Good for a first try, but you'll have to try harder than that to
get a
> good flamefest going. :-)
>
> You see, to my mind you've described integration testing. This is
very
> important and needful to deliver software quality, but you're still
> only testing the joined together building blocks.

I was not talking about integration testing. But indeed I am thinking
about testing at a higher level within the unit itself.


> Does it not make
> sense to ensure that the blocks you're joining together are of high
> quality?
>

Yes.

> Simon
>

Regards, Jan
